importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the game that led to the ALCS Game 7, marking a pivotal moment in the postseason.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe highlights the progression of the ALCS, including the previous game where Seattle scored five runs in four innings, and the current Game 7 that followed.

keyTakeAways: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hit his sixth home run of the postseason, extending the Blue Jays' lead to 5-0 and sealing the series.
The Seattle Mariners committed three errors, two in quick succession, which allowed Toronto to score early and maintain dominance.
The Blue Jays will face the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, with Game 1 on Friday.
Seattle becomes the first team without a pennant to play a Game 7 in its history.
Toronto has played a Game 7 only twice, the first since 1985, emphasizing the significance of this matchup.
Josh Naylor's home run and Randy Arozerana's single gave the Mariners a brief run in the sixth inning, but a wild pitch by Matt Brash ultimately led to a 6-2 final score.

22-year-old pitcher Yesevage delivered a strong performance with 31 splitters, seven strikeouts, and only six hits and three walks, showcasing composure and defensive support that helped secure the win.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Guerrero Jr.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He hit his sixth home run in the postseason, a pivotal moment that contributed directly to the Blue Jays' victory and advancement to Game 7 of the ALCS.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays won the game 6-2, forcing a decisive Game 7 in the ALCS and marking their first such game since 1985, highlighting their significance in the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners lost the game 6-2, committing critical errors and failing to score consistently, resulting in their first Game 7 appearance in history.

namedEntities.name: American League Championship Series (ALCS)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is the current playoff series between the Blue Jays and Mariners, which concluded with a 6-2 win for Toronto and a forced Game 7.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The winner of the ALCS will face the Dodgers in the World Series, marking the next stage of the 2025 MLB postseason.

namedEntities.name: Yesevage
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: 22-year-old pitcher Yesevage delivered a strong performance with 31 splitters, seven strikeouts, and only six hits and three walks, showing composure and helping secure the Blue Jays' win.

namedEntities.name: Julio Rodríguez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He committed a fielding error on a single from Daulton Varsho, contributing to the Mariners’ early scoring problems.

namedEntities.name: Daulton Varsho
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He reached second base due to a fielding error by Julio Rodríguez, initiating a scoring sequence that led to early runs for Toronto.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He hit a groundball that resulted in a fielding error by Eugenio Suárez, leading to a two-run RBI hit by Addison Barger.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He lost the ball during a transfer throw, leading to a groundball error that allowed runs to score.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He scored two runs with a two-run homer and later contributed an RBI single, helping the Blue Jays build a lead early.

namedEntities.name: Isiah Kiner-Falefa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He scored an RBI with a single after a fielding error, contributing to the Blue Jays' early 2-0 lead.

namedEntities.name: Josh Naylor
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He homered in the sixth inning to give the Mariners a brief run, showing that Seattle had some offensive potential.

namedEntities.name: Randy Arozerana
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He scored on a single that knocked out Trey Yesavage after 87 pitches, adding a run for the Mariners in the sixth inning.

namedEntities.name: Trey Yesavage
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was removed from the game after 87 pitches due to a hit by a single from Randy Arozerana, marking a critical defensive moment.

namedEntities.name: Matt Brash
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He issued a wild pitch in the seventh inning that allowed Vladimir Guerrero Jr. to score, sealing the 6-2 lead and forcing Game 7.

namedEntities.name: Louis Varland
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He relieved in the sixth inning and gave up a single to Suárez, who scored to extend the Mariners’ run.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hits his sixth home run of the postseason, helping the Toronto Blue Jays defeat the Seattle Mariners 6-2 to force a decisive Game 7 in the American League Championship Series. The Mariners committed three errors—two in quick succession—leading to early runs for Toronto, including back-to-back RBI singles by Addison Barger and Isiah Kiner-Falefa. Despite a brief rally with a homer from Josh Naylor and a single by Randy Arozerana, the Blue Jays maintained their lead thanks to a wild pitch by Matt Brash that allowed Guerrero to score. The Blue Jays, who have not played a Game 7 since 1985, now face the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, with Game 1 set for Friday. This marks the first time the Mariners have played a Game 7 in their history, highlighting the significance of the matchup.
title: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. hits sixth homer of postseason as Blue Jays dominate Mariners to force ALCS Game 7
